headline: Great Place to Work
pros: If you want to be a coverage or product banker, Moelis is the cream of the crop. The firm is large enough with enough name recognition to bring in top-tier clients, but is small enough to change and adapt to the changing landscape and add new technologies/features that make employee lives better. Deal teams are very lean and the analyst experience is very good (long hours, but very interesting deals and working directly on the model).
cons: Only con is hours. You won't have much of a work life balance here, but it really strongly depends which MDs you work under - some care less about work-life, but others are very sensitive to it and really try to make sure junior bankers don't burn out.

The organisation and brand are respected in the US market where there are some genuinely good bankers.

In the London office, Moelis has earned every bit of its terrible reputation for poisonous politics and a churn and burn approach to people at every level. 
There are some good people but the average quality of the senior team in London is poor compared to other boutiques and to its own US offices.
Progression internally is limited by these issues

headline: Terrible IT Experience
pros: Free pizza and beers on Friday afternoon
cons:
The IT management team is constantly turning over, there are countless outages.  I've personally lost data and the IT team has been unable to get it back, literally losing 100s of hours of work. 

IT management constantly changes direction, they don't bother to ask the business what the community wants, instead they run with their own agenda, separate to business requirements. 

Our IT team is so far behind our competitors, it's not even funny, Windows 7 and Office 2010, ridiculous! 

Constantly work 100 hour + weeks, not appreciated by management, no room for advancement, no work life balance.

headline: Overall Good Experience
pros:
- Company Culture
- Great benefits
- Hard work and a great work ethic are acknowledged and appreciated
cons:
- Limited training for non-bankers
- Most teams are very lean. This can mean great exposure and access to senior managers but often led to an overwhelming work load.

headline: Investment Banking Analyst

- Company culture
- Deal flow

headline: Investment Banking Summer Analyst

headline: Administrative Assistant
pros: Good Benefits, International Offices, Publicly Traded Company
cons: Lack of an office culture

headline: Fantastic Colleagues, Sub-Par Action from Management
pros: Wonderful people, responsibility-oriented work and the ability to create your own path are all strong positives. On most teams, it is a meritocracy - if you prove you are intelligent and have the ability to handle the work, teams are more than willing to allow you to run with a project.
cons: The IB experience at Moelis is very binary, depending on which teams you end up working with. There are certain teams who care very little about your work/life balance, professional development, or general happiness. They are in the minority, but there are far too many left after 5+ of junior bankers raising the issues to Management - they should have been weeded out long ago. One bad deal team can destroy your year-end review, whether or not you were the actual problem.

headline: 2nd Year Investment Banking Analyst
pros: Good Compensation, Fast growing company
cons: Extremely tough hours, lots of politics involved in work environment, lack of mentorship

headline: Former employee
pros: Incredibly smart and very good at what they do - particularly top specialists in special situatikns
cons: Political culture, face-time, zero females, minimal focus on career development or team consistency.

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
1. Solid brand
2. Good deals and exposure
3. Great compensation
4. Lot of freedom to do small deals
cons:
1. Needs to improve IT infrastructure
2. Sector teams not the best
3. Europe business not particularly strong, areas of strength are in USA and India

headline: Solid place to work
pros: I've met some of the best people here.  Knowledgeable,dedicated and hard working - solid teamwork.
cons: The work hours are extremely challenging.

headline: (Well paying) sweatshop
pros:
- above avg. (mostly cash) compensation 
- consistent deal flow and good learning experience (especially for jr. bankers)
- limited bureaucracy (no need for multiple internal committee meetings)
cons:
- some of the worst hours on the street and no attempts to address it; results in high turnover and a scramble for lateral talent every year
- experience is largely dependent on who you work with and the range is enormous 
- limited brand awareness outside of IBD; not a great platform to exit unless you're an analyst

headline: Good firm but long hours
pros: Great people, gained responsibilities early on
cons: Very very long hours, lower bonus

headline: Great Firm
pros: Excellent experience at the firm.
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: Stay Away
pros: Great experience that is much more hands on than other top tier banks.
cons: They care little about your long term career goals. Even though they do not punish recruitment at other firms, the workload is so unbelievably high (even in comparison with other banks) that there is no time for anything other than Moelis.

headline: Demanding but good for learning the ropes as an Analyst
pros: Growing firm with smart bankers and good deal flow. Lots of room to step up and take responsibility.Significant opportunity to interact with senior bankers
cons: Formal training is limited compared to big banks. Also fewer support roles require the deal team to do more (a positive and a negative - see more of the overall deal but also need to cover multiple functional areas). Brutal lifestyle but firm is aware of this and working to improve.

headline: Honest review
pros: Great location in Midtown and access to plenty of stores and eateries on Lexington Ave. Good access to trains and express buses. Good pay (but you have to prove you deserve it - they will verify pay from previous employers). Pizza Friday's in a small kitchen.
cons: Cliquey staff and middle management blocks advancement. If they don't move up then you don't move up even if you deserve it. Bankers and execs don't mingle with the support staff they just stay in their wooden and glass offices. Admins think they run the show and are constantly fighting amongst themselves. They are supervised by a higher admin who they walk all over. Operations teams couldn't get it together if their life depended on it. Place looks and feels outdated in front and back of house. Wood throughout entire entrance space looks like an old school 80s law firm. Back areas looks like an insane alyssum/off white color only dingier. The IT systems are a joke and our inboxes were always hit with spam followed by "Do not open those emails" notices once or twice a week. It's an embarrassment that a company that wealthy can't get simple infrastructure issues addressed once and for all. the HR is like every other company that is run by sorority sisters. No work life balance for staff, not family friendly and when one banker jumped out a window, it was only a brief mention by the top brass. Nothing changed the culture and people are still expected to work like dogs through all hours of the night. Don't expect company picnics or company activities with the exception of a company Christmas party that is always stale since nobody mingles outside of their pay grade circle. Not friendly. No one even mingles at pizza friday they grab their food and go.

headline: Hard work - Know you are signing up to work hard
pros: Will Work very hard. Will be in the midst of a dynamic environment. Will learn mmuch and will be prepared for any next steps in adjacent fields
cons: Long hours, very hierarchical at the lower level

headline: It's an OK place to work but very low in interesting projects right now.
pros:
Very talented colleagues.
Good work environment.
Free english classes.
Flexible arrival and departure work hours.
Free coffee.
cons:
Not very challenging projects to work for.
Low salaries.
Not good transparency from the management.
The office is just too small for the amount of workers.
It is too far sited from the main cities of the region.
No lunch bonuses.

headline: Place is good, but can be much much better
pros: Strong deal flow,responsibility, compensation and generalist structure. Savvy senior members who are hungry.  Positive macro trend with more business shifting to boutiques if the firm can retain people once lockups expire.
cons: A select handful of VPs and MDs at Moelis just ruin it for everyone. The firm minus those individuals (mid-level and senior especially in media, healthcare and some others which maybe I'll hint at another time) as well as some terribly pathetic associates make what could be a decent experience, horrible.  It's why the only reason (and i stress 'only' very seriously) junior folks (including associates, yes you read right) join solely so they can get a brand name on their resume and recruit right away. Many many associates and VPs are currently recruiting at funds and other banks.  And if comp ever lost its premium over other places, Moelis would lose all its top talent to other places as well as hiring power for future years.

headline: Analyst
pros: Great Learning experience, Great Pay, Great Benefits
cons: Lifestyle and unrealistic expectations due to lack of communication

headline: Tough hours, even for banking
pros: Generalist experience exposes you to staffings on multiple industries and products. No shortage of modeling experience.
cons:
Hours were brutal. Get caught with the wrong team and you will consistently work until 2-3 every day for weeks at a time. May be better now as they have since hired lots of additional analysts.

Lots of pitching - few of the senior bankers are any good at  using analyst / associate resources efficiently... Problem with there being many analysts now means that you are less likely to get exposure to good deals as there are not always lots to go around.

headline: Good
pros: Good deal flow good experience good teamwork
cons: Small team, hard hours, no graduate hire structure

headline: Analyst
pros: Great culture, Street-leading compensation, great deal flow
cons: Long hours and less work/life balance policies than elsewhere on the Street

headline: High pay, but you have to sell your soul for it
pros: Plenty of smart and thoughtful people with great experience. Lots of real and challenging workflow. High pay if you're willing to give up your life - literally.
cons: ZERO work/life balance - worse than the typically bad reputation most investment banks rightfully receive. Working all day on Saturday AND Sunday is a minimum expectation even if/when on vacation. As an example, after working two full Saturdays in a row, I made it clear to my working teams that I had a wedding the coming Saturday night and would like to work remotely should anything come up. Sure enough, something came up (something ALWAYS does) so I logged on and started working. I ended up missing the wedding - one of my oldest friends from high school - and if that wasn't enough, I was later reprimanded by HR because they claimed that since I wasn't physically in the office I showed a "lack of engagement/commitment" and that my absence caused "inefficiencies in the work process" - even though we finished the work ahead of the deadline and it was later praised by the senior bankers and client as "outstanding work." This place demands facetime, rewards those who work hardest (not smartest), and now that it's public is continuing to be run more and more by HR and the bureaucrats . . . something Ken Moelis pledged not to let happen when he first started the firm. Moelis is a great place to work for a year or two if you're looking to build your skill set and experience, but anything beyond that is soul crushing.

headline: Tough slog
pros: Good firm reputation. Generalist experience.
cons: No personal time whatsoever. Always on call. Poor project management skills from many senior and mid-level bankers.

headline: Investment Banking Analyst
pros:
- Lots of responsibilities for junior bankers due to fewer mid-level layers
 - Competitive compensation (though that seems to be the bulk of the satisfaction on the job) 
 - Decent brand name on Wall Street which helps recruiting
cons:
- Poor work-life balance and culture (though looking to improve due to recent tragedies with junior bankers) which lead to low morale
 - Sr. bankers care very little about what's going on with the junior bankers
 - Lack infrastructure and resources
 - High turnover

headline: Executive Assistant
pros: The EAs are a good team and help each other out
cons:
EAs are treated with no respect
High turnover of EAs so constantly having to cover 
Management for EA team are unable to communicate and will not make a decision 
You are not allowed to have an opinion you will only do well of you put up and keep  your mouth shut
No job stability I have seen them on many occasions  try and manage people out just because they were not liked by the manager
Very much us and them,  bankers get treated  a lot better and been told on many occassions that they are a priority

headline: Analyst - chicago
pros: Moelis name brand. Good office space.
cons: Pathetic experience (mostly pitches) and arrogant associates

headline: Worked in small teams to advise companies on M&A

cons: Expected to work obnoxious hours even by banking standards. On call 24/7 and even vacations are waved off if you are "needed" in the office

headline: Solid

headline: Not good

headline: Avoid at all costs...unless the pros are enough to entice you
pros:
- Good pay and bonus levels compared to other Investment Banks
- Good social aspect i.e xmas parties, dinners etc
- Good in-office perks i.e free coffee, tea, pizza Fridays etc
cons:
- A senior management team that lead an 'aggressive', 'self-serving' and 'blame' culture 
- There is an expectation to work very long hours
- Senior management is a 'closed' shop

headline: Moelis is a newer name on Wall Street but everyone knows what it is given the history of its senior folks.  Great place.
pros: Meritocracy, strong compensation, great exit (and promotion) opportunities and great deal-flow!  Great place to work and its changed drastically for the better from its older days.
cons: Hours are bad but that's an industry wide phenomenon and given its strong dealflow, hours will stay like this.

headline: Poorly structured

Relaxed approach to work e.g. dress down Fridays 
Allowed to come in later if you have worked until the small hours
cons:
Almost non existent training and development prospects. 
High turnover of people 
'us and them' office culture 
work/life balance is poor
London offices in dire need of a reorganisation! There is no natural light on the first floor! As an Analyst working long hours this was terrible.

headline: Zero Work-life Balance
pros: Great pay and a promising career path if you fit in their mold.
cons: Even by banking standards, hours were very long for both bankers and back office.  Average benefits.  Lack of foresight by senior managers resulted in many fire drills.
